title: Would Sylas ever team up with Noxus?
body:
I know that quote from him (_"Noxian swine, Demacian swine. They'll all end up at the slaughter"_) seems to indicate he sees Noxus as no better, but they're mortal enemies of Demacia, mage friendly and led by a mage.

You think he'd eventually ally with them or Noxus would try and reach out to him?

replies.body:
I thought about it during his development. I thought a lot about all the champions and regions!

If Sylas was born there he'd probably be Swain's right hand man - an assassin/rogue like Katarina perhaps. Being able to trace magic helps you not only hunt targets but spot magical traps, see through illusions and circumvent protection. It's sad really. You are right also that a powerful nation that embraces magic would make a useful ally for a band of rogue mages unwittingly camping on a secret vault of worldstones.

Alas being in a dungeon for his entire adult life Sylas probably knows very little of Noxus (and I believe the factions encountered each other late enough there might not be many records in old books he had access to), and would be immediately wary of any empire and their rhetoric. He's not exactly the trusting type.  Swain would be all like 'In Noxus, strength is what decides who leads!' and Sylas would say 'And yet here I see at the top of the pile, a cripple who had to borrow his power...'

Sylas' line about Noxus likely comes from a place or ignorance or at least indifference. I know it makes it confusing but I don't think you can always trust that our champions are speaking truthfully. Or with wisdom! Except Zoe. She has it all figured out.

...Wow. Didn't expect an actual Rioter to weigh in. Neat.

People tend to forget that Sylas isn't JUST against Demacian anti-mage policy. It's the anti-mage policy influenced by Demacias' social classes.

Like in the Vietnam War people weren't just against the war, but pointed out the clear hypocrisy of only the poor being drafted.

"Ain't no senators' son" {{sticker:sona-playing}} 

Noxus is becoming a meritocracy but still has nobility that probably don't like Swains' reforms and want an emperor they can back that will reward first them before all the rest of the rabble. That's why the nobility make up the crux of The Black Roses' pawns.

Sylas probably wouldn't like them very much.
Spot on in my opinion. The treatment of mages is only a symptom of the class structure in Demacia.

Yeah... Which is why it made me so angry to see Sylas depicted as a villain... As it stands right now, the story of Sylas seems to say: "it's complicated, maybe classism and privileges are actually good? Maybe the nobles are right to oppress the poors? Because look at what happens when we let them do what they want."

And that's disgusting.

There were already a lot of interesting stories to tell with a morally firm Sylas with strong principles but questionable means to fight against the class structure. But no, it had to be muddied by making him selfish, and concerned about revenge, and abusing/exploiting the mages in his rebellion for his personal agenda.

That doesn't make him a more nuanced character, that only makes him a more despicable one, when he's actually on the right side of history. Sad.

Then stop seeing everything in black and white.
Sylas is a villain in this storyline, but that doesn't mean that he doesn't have a point.

And honestly its much more interesting this way.
If Sylas was good and the other side was evil, then it'd be obvious for which side you should root, but this way its kinda difficult to do that since both sides are right in some aspects, but wrong in others and the question is how this will be resolved eventually, because if either side would ever achieve total victory, then that would be an unsatisfying conclusion.

> If Sylas was good and the other side was evil, then it'd be obvious for which side you should root,

It IS obvious. Even now, even with Sylas as a villain. **That**'s the problem. Demacia oppression of mages is horrible, and it has been made clear in the Lux comic multiple times. The customs of Demacia are wrong, plain, flat out wrong.

Except the guy most ardently fighting against them is ALSO an asshole, working on his personal revenge and wanting to murder people. That's not a "more nuances of grey" kinda situation, that's a "black & black" kinda situation.

Seriously, how can you accuse me of "seeing everything in black & white" when I wrote this: "a lot of interesting stories to tell with a morally firm Sylas with strong principles but questionable means".  How is that black & white?

The thing is that Riot doesn't try to hide it that Sylas has a point and that the mage opression is bad.

Sylas is pretty much meant to be the monster that was created by society. He is the evil that was created by Demacias sense of justice.

Also while J4 got the mages imprisoned, there hasn't been confirmation that he outright murders them.

Making Sylas morally firm, but with questionable means would have simply plunged him into the role of the anti-hero in this scenario, making it obvious that either Sylas would win, or a peaceful resolution will be found eventually. Having Sylas be outright evil, makes it much harder to imagine a peaceful resolution, even though that would likely be the best outcome for both sides.

> Having Sylas be outright evil, makes it much harder to imagine a peaceful resolution, even though that would likely be the best outcome for both sides.

I agree with that, but how is that a good thing?! How does it make for more compelling storytelling? Or more relatable characters? A better story that you can invest yourself into?

It keeps the story less predictable and thats usually a good thing(at least most of the time), because it keeps the viewer/reader guessing whats going to happen. I mean if I can predict already the rest of the story, then why should I even bother reading it?


It also makes the government side of the conflict less evil. Sylas is definitely not someone who should succeed, because if he did, then demacia would fall into total chaos. So the government not yielding to him is definitely understandable. If Sylas was morally good, then the government would be pretty much just evil for not negotiating with him or trying to fight him by actually improving the situation for the mages.

Last but not least, it actually gives us a pretty good example of how violence causes more violence. Demacia surpressed magic because of the horrible things that magic did in the past, this caused Sylas to become evil and his actions caused Jarvan IV to double down on the anti-mage politics.

> It also makes the government side of the conflict less evil. Sylas is definitely not someone who should succeed, because if he did, then demacia would fall into total chaos. So the government not yielding to him is definitely understandable. If Sylas was morally good, then the government would be pretty much just evil for not negotiating with him or trying to fight him by actually improving the situation for the mages.

No offense mate, but who's seeing things in B&W now? You're basically saying "one side must be the villain", but no, you can have conflict between two opposing factions and none of them evil.

People do mistakes all the time, the inertia of culture and customs is super hard to overcome. Not to mention that even non-evil people can get tangled in their emotions sometimes, and this creates misunderstandings. All in all, it was perfectly possible to have a credible and nuanced conflict between the nobles in power and the rebellion without any of the two sides being straight out villainous.

> It keeps the story less predictable

Really? Because my bet is still that Demacia nobility will realize the error of their ways and become more accepting of the mages in the end, probably under the impulsion of Lux. As for Sylas, he's a champion, so he'll never die, so either he will be redeemed, or he will be exiled (maybe work for Noxus as this thread suggest). Which is more or less the same bet I would have done with Sylas as an anti-hero instead of a villain.

> I mean if I can predict already the rest of the story, then why should I even bother reading it?

With that logic, why watch any action movie ever? And yet we all still do. Or fairy tales, they're all the same, from a structural point of view, and yet people have loved them for literally centuries. A lot of the interest of a story is in the execution, not the structure.

I haven't played Sylas and don't know his quotes, but from the Lux comic and his lore I get that the whole thing about freeing the mages is just an excuse to gain power? As in, Demacia does have a problem with social classes and magic, but I feel Sylas doesn't really believe in his cause, it's more a story he tells to exploit all the poor, oppressed mages in Demacia. To me he just wants to ovethrow the Demacian nobility and politics, and become ruler of a nation and an army.
In that sense, Noxus would be a dangerous ally, because Sylas' forces aren't strong enough to not be exploited and absorbed by Noxus. Noxus would sure be useful to Sylas' fight against Demacia, but I think for now it would be too risky for him to ally with them
